The Main Thread

Detailed Description

One of the threads on which pMath runs is called the main thread (by default, the thread, thatd called pmath_init first). This main thread can be interrupted during evaluation by any other thread to evaluate something else.

The main thread should survive all other threads. However, if the main thread terminates and another thread calls pmath_main_interrupt[_wait]() the interrupt will simply be discarded.

Function Documentation

PMATH_API pmath_object_t pmath_main_interrupt_wait ( pmath_object_t  object  ) 

Evaluate something in the main thread and return the result.

Parameters:
object A pMath object. It will be freed.
Returns:
The result of the evaluation or PMATH_UNDEFINED on error.

PMATH_API void pmath_main_interrupt ( pmath_object_t  object  ) 

Evaluate something in the main thread but do not wait for the result.

Parameters:
object A pMath object. It will be freed.
If the calling thread is the main thread, pmath_unref(pmath_evaluate(object)) is called. Otherwise, the function return immediately after enqueueing object for evalution in the main thread.

PMATH_API void pmath_main_takeover ( void   ) 

Change the main thread.

Make the current thread the main thread.

PMATH_API pmath_boolean_t pmath_main_is_current ( void   ) 

Test if the current thread is the main thread.

Returns:
Whether the current thread is the main thread.

PMATH_API void pmath_main_sleep ( void   ) 

Suspend the current (main) thread until an interrupt occurs.

If the current thread is not the main thread, this function returns immediately. Otherwise it does not return until pmath_main_wakeup() is called directly or indirecly by e.g. pmath_main_interrupt(). Finally, pmath_aborting() is called to handle all pending interrupts.

PMATH_API void pmath_main_wakeup ( void   ) 

Wake up the main thread.

This makes the main thread return from pmath_main_sleep() if it is there.
